# Challenge Name: RS4


![date](https://img.shields.io/badge/date-07.03.2022-brightgreen.svg)  
![solved after CTF](https://img.shields.io/badge/solved-after%20CTF-red.svg)  
![category](https://img.shields.io/badge/category-Crypto-blueviolet.svg)   
![value](https://img.shields.io/badge/value-15-blue.svg)  

## Description  

Created By sicmundos

Bob sent the flag to Alice and Eve, try to find it.

[Download Attachement](https://s3.eu-west-3.amazonaws.com/crisis-assets/crisis_attachements/XCtDwyIanp8Gk7RgZClyM42xqD8bXULIl1Du1PIG.zip)

## Detailed solution

Start by checking the atteachement file. We have 4 files, 2 keys and 2 encoded flags

**Key1**

```
N = 

e=17

```

**Key2**

```
N = 

e=65537

```

We can see modulus N and public exponent e used for RSA public key

We have the same modulus N for both keys, we can perform a common modulus attack on RSA

Given two ciphertext, encrypted with the same modulus N, but a different exponent e, it is possible to recover the plaintext of the message. In order for this attack to work, the greatest common denominator of the two exponent should be 1 : gcd(e1, e2) = 1.

You can read more about this attack at https://medium.com/bugbountywriteup/rsa-attacks-common-modulus-7bdb34f331a5

We gonna use this tool https://github.com/HexPandaa/RSA-Common-Modulus-Attack

But first we need to create public keys. I'll use https://github.com/Ganapati/RsaCtfTool

We need to : 
- Convert modulus N from hex to decimal
- Create public keys using N and e
- Convert flags to base64
- Use the tool for decryption https://github.com/HexPandaa/RSA-Common-Modulus-Attack

```bash
python3 RsaCtfTool.py --createpub -n  -e 17
```

```bash
RsaCtfTool.py --createpub -n  -e 65537
```

```

```
Now save those public keys to files

Let's encode flag. I forgot about it during ctf --'

```bash
┌──(kali㉿kali)-[~]
└─$ base64 R54/flag.enc1 > 1.b64                                          

┌──(kali㉿kali)-[~]
└─$ base64 R54/flag.enc2 > 2.b64 
```

Now let's decrypt the message using : 

```bash
python3 rsa-cm.py -c1 <ciphertext1> -c2 <ciphertext2> -k1 <publickey1> -k2 <publickey2>
```

## Flag

```
CRISIS{N0_54m3_M0dulu5}
```
